metadata.case_name: Builders Supply Corporation v. Union of India

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 secured a building contract from the Government for construction of the Mint and deposited Rs. 50,000 as security with Superintending Engineer, Calcutta Central Circle No. 1.
Appellant supplied building materials to respondent No. 2 for the contract but was unable to secure payment.
On 18th April 1949, appellant obtained order for attachment before judgment of Rs. 5,000 out of security deposit.
On 16th June 1950, appellant's suit decreed by 5th Additional Subordinate Judge, 24 Parganas, for Rs. 12,275-9-0.
On 14th February 1952, appellant put decree in execution in court of 7th Sub-Judge, starting Money Execution Case No. 9 of 1952; order for attachment of further Rs. 7,275-9-0 out of security deposit.
Subordinate Judge wrote to Superintending Engineer to remit Rs. 5,000 already attached; Engineer attached further amount but did not remit.
On 30th April 1952, Executing Court asked Engineer to transmit whole Rs. 12,275-9-0; not complied till March 9, 1953.

On 23rd July 1952, Certificate Officer wrote to Subordinate Judge requesting withholding of payment to appellant to enable claim under O.21 r.52 CPC; informed Engineer not to pay out of deposit after deducting departmental dues, as income-tax arrears exceeded Rs. 50,000.
Despite letter, Superintending Engineer sent attached amount to Executing Court, received on 9th March 1953.
On 21st March 1953, Executing Court wrote to Certificate Officer requiring reasons why amount should not be paid to appellant, warning payment by 10th April 1953 if no step taken.
Commissioner of Income-tax intervened, sought adjournments, intimated would show cause.
On 17th June 1953, Certificate Officer wrote under Rule 22 Schedule II Recovery Act asking court to hold amount subject to further intimation; received 24th June 1953; court withheld payment.

On 15th July 1953 and 11th September 1953, respondent No. 1 applied claiming priority for income-tax arrears 1946-47 and 1947-48; alleged certificate under s.46(2) Income-tax Act forwarded to Collector.
Executing Court upheld respondent No. 1's priority claim, directed payment of Rs. 12,275-9-0 to respondent No. 1.
Appellant challenged via revision under s.115 CPC to Calcutta High Court; High Court discharged rule on 21st June 1955, upholding priority.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondent No. 1, Union of India, is entitled to claim priority for tax due from respondent No. 2 for assessment years 1946-47 and 1947-48 over decretal amount due to appellant from respondent No. 2.
Whether common law doctrine of Crown debts priority applies post-Constitution under Art. 372(1).
Whether doctrine displaced by s.46 Income-tax Act 1922 and Public Demands Recovery Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Common law doctrine of Crown prerogative priority does not apply post-Constitution as inconsistent with Art. 372(1).
Doctrine displaced by specific provisions of Income-tax Act s.46 and Recovery Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.46 Income-tax Act 1922; Public Demands Recovery Act; Attorney General v. De Keyser's Royal Hotel; Governor-General v. Shromani Sugar Mills

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Recovery Act prevent claim for priority in this case.

respondent_arguments.text: Tax dues have priority over unsecured creditors under common law doctrine recognized in India.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Common law; s.46(2) Income-tax Act; precedents like Manickam Chettiar v. ITO

respondent_arguments.text: Doctrine continues post-Constitution as law in force under Art. 372(1).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 372(1); Director of Rationing v. Corporation of Calcutta

court_reasoning.text: Common law doctrine of priority for Crown/tax debts over private unsecured debts recognized consistently by Indian High Courts pre-Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Doctrine rooted in common law prerogative, also paralleled in ancient Hindu jurisprudence.

court_reasoning.text: Doctrine constitutes 'law in force' under Art. 372(1), continues post-Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Per Director of Rationing case, common law rules on substantive rights are included.

court_reasoning.text: s.46 Income-tax Act provides recovery modes as arrears of land revenue but does not address or displace priority doctrine.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section merely procedural for recovery, not exhaustive.

court_reasoning.text: Recovery Act procedural for public demands, including tax arrears; Rule 22 allows claims but does not displace common law priority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No provision directly covers or abrogates priority principle.

holdings.text: Union of India entitled to priority for income-tax arrears over appellant's decretal debt from same debtor.
Common law priority doctrine for tax dues is law in force under Art. 372(1).
Doctrine not displaced by Income-tax Act s.46 or Recovery Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State v. Bombay Landing Shipping Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld priority of Crown judgment debts in India.

precedents_cited.case_name: Manickam Chettiar v. Income-tax Officer Madura
precedents_cited.relevance: Income-tax debt has priority over private debts; s.46 not exhaustive.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bank of India v. John Bowman
precedents_cited.relevance: Priority based on principle Crown prevails over subject for equal debts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kaka Mohamed Ghouse Sahib Co. v. United Commercial Syndicate
precedents_cited.relevance: Republican Constitution does not abrogate State debts priority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Director of Rationing v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Common law rules on substantive rights are 'law in force' under Art. 372(1).
Obiter doubts on priority dismissed as outweighed by authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Attorney General v. De Keyser's Royal Hotel Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Prerogative abridged only by specific statutory conditions; not applicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Governor-General v. Shromani Sugar Mills Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: s.230 Companies Act limits priority; Recovery Act does not.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Provides modes for recovery of tax arrears as land revenue; not exhaustive, does not displace priority.

statutes_cited.name: Public Demands Recovery Act (Bengal)
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedural for recovering public demands including tax; Rule 22 for attachment in court custody, allows priority claims.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs execution, attachments; High Court invoked r.52 with Recovery Act Rule 22.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Continues pre-Constitution laws including common law doctrines as 'law in force'.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Calcutta High Court and Executing Court's decision that Union of India's income-tax arrears have priority over appellant's decretal amount; directed payment to Union.
outcome.relief_granted: Priority and payment of Rs. 12,275-9-0 to Union of India.

key_quotes.text: "the short question of law which arises in this appeal is whether respondent No. 1, the Union of India, is entitled to claim that the tax due to it from respondent No. 2... has priority and precedence over the decretal amount due to the appellant"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "this decision clearly shows that the rules of Common Law relating to substantive rights which had been adopted by this country and enforced by judicial decisions, amount to law in force... within the meaning of Art. 372(1)"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on constitutional continuity of doctrine.

key_quotes.text: "Our conclusion, therefore, is that the claim for priority made by respondent No. 1 in the present proceedings has to be sustained"
key_quotes.speaker: court
